content.webTitle: Tiger Woods’ future in doubt after he pulls out of Farmers Insurance Open

fields.headline: Tiger Woods’ future in doubt after he pulls out of Farmers Insurance Open
fields.bodyText: The golfing future of Tiger Woods has been plunged into serious doubt once again, after the 14-times major winner was forced to withdraw from the Farmers Insurance Open at Torrey Pines, 12 holes into his first round. Woods was in clear discomfort throughout his time on the course, the 39-year-old routinely holding his back after shots and limping. Even his playing partner, Billy Horschel, took to lifting Woods’s tee peg from the ground and picking his ball from the hole on occasion. Remarkably, Woods played his first 10 holes in level par but he slipped to a double-bogey six on his 11th. This was painful viewing. By the 3rd green, Woods’s 12th, he decided enough was enough. This marks Woods’s third mid-tournament withdrawal in eight starts and the fifth time since 2011 he has been forced into such a move. Woods drove straight from the California venue, rather than heading for on-site physiotherapy treatment. The timing could barely be worse, with the first major of the season, the Masters, nine weeks away. Woods missed the cut in his first event of the year, the Waste Management Phoenix Open, last weekend having shot a second round of 82 – his worst as a professional – but insisted his health was fine. Back surgery caused him to miss a chunk of last year, including the Masters, so there will be obvious and deep-rooted concern regarding his latest setback. Speaking from the car park at Torrey Pines, Woods insisted that a delay of two and a half hours for fog had played a part in his problem. Onlookers described him as looking uncomfortable during his warm-up. “It’s just my glutes are shutting off,” he said. “They don’t activate, hence it goes into my lower back. It is frustrating that I just can’t stay activated. It just got progressively tighter.” The former world No1 had started this week as 56th in the PGA Tour rankings. His position will now drop further, decreasing his chances of featuring in the WGC-Cadillac Championship in Doral at the start of March. Not for the first time, however, Woods has bigger issues with which to concern himself.
